Repeat echo at 3 months to guide duration. 4. NOACs are not approved for LV thrombus. 5. Sudden maximal deficit at onset suggests cardioembolism.
explanation.references: 1. Hart RG et al. Antithrombotic Therapy in Patients with Left Ventricular Thrombus. N Engl J Med. 2014;371(21):2003–2013. 2. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Stroke Prevention, Stroke. 2014;45(7):2160–2236. 3. Vaitkus PT, Barnathan ES. Embolic Potential of Left Ventricular Thrombi. Circulation. 1994;89(1):252–256.

question: In a typical scenario of CADASIL, which gene is associated with the condition?

explanation.option_analysis: Option C is correct: CADASIL (cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy) is caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene on chromosome 19. Pathogenic variants lead to granular osmiophilic material deposition in vascular smooth muscle cells, resulting in small vessel pathology with recurrent subcortical ischemic events and leukoencephalopathy (Joutel et al., 1996). NOTCH1 and NOTCH2 mutations cause Alagille syndrome and Hajdu–Cheney syndrome respectively, while NOTCH4 has no known human disease association. Common board-level distractors include NOTCH1 and NOTCH2, but CADASIL is classically tied to NOTCH3. This is universally taught in vascular neurology and genetics of stroke.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: CADASIL is an inherited SVD classified under ICD-11 9A23. It presents with migraine with aura, recurrent subcortical TIAs/strokes, cognitive decline, and mood disturbances. Histopathology shows arteriolar wall thickening and GOM deposition. It fits within hereditary small vessel diseases alongside CARASIL and hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Differential includes MS, vasculitis, and mitochondrial encephalopathies. Embryologically, NOTCH signaling regulates vascular development; mutations impair vascular smooth muscle cell differentiation. Neuroanatomically, white matter tracts—especially periventricular regions, external capsules, and anterior temporal lobes—are most affected.
explanation.pathophysiology: Normal NOTCH3 receptor function maintains vascular smooth muscle cell homeostasis via ligand-induced cleavage and nuclear translocation of the Notch intracellular domain, regulating gene transcription. CADASIL mutations cluster in extracellular EGF-like repeats, leading to misfolded proteins and GOM accumulation. This disrupts cell–cell adhesion, causes lumen narrowing, hypoperfusion, and chronic ischemia. The ischemic cascade activates glial scarring and axonal loss in subcortical white matter. Over time, progressive hypoxia results in lacunar infarcts, arteriolar wall thickening, and myelin pallor, manifesting as clinical strokes and cognitive impairment.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: The mean age of onset is 45 years, with migraine in 30–40% and ischemic events in 60–80%. Cognitive decline evolves over 10–15 years post-symptom onset, often leading to dementia by the sixth decade. Psychiatric manifestations (depression, apathy) occur in 20–30%. MRI shows confluent white matter hyperintensities, especially in anterior temporal poles (90% sensitivity) and external capsules (95% sensitivity). Lacunes appear later in basal ganglia and thalamus. Pedigree analysis reveals autosomal dominant inheritance with complete penetrance by age 65.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: First-tier: brain MRI demonstrating characteristic WMH distribution; family history. Second-tier: genetic testing for NOTCH3 mutations—sensitivity >95% for known pathogenic variants. Skin biopsy ultrastructure to detect GOM in vascular smooth muscle cells is third-tier if genetic testing inconclusive. CSF and angiography rule out mimics. Pre-test probability high in patients with early onset strokes, migraines, and family history. Genetic counseling is essential.
explanation.management_principles: No disease-modifying therapy exists. Management is supportive: antiplatelet therapy to reduce stroke risk (aspirin 75–100 mg daily). Control of vascular risk factors, migraine prophylaxis (verapamil), and management of mood symptoms (SSRIs). Physical and cognitive rehabilitation as indicated. Investigational approaches include NOTCH3 pathway modulators and gene therapy in clinical trials.
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Yearly neurologic evaluation with MRI every 1–2 years to monitor WMH progression. Cognitive testing and psychiatric screening annually. Blood pressure control with target <130/80 mm Hg. Family screening with genetic counseling for first-degree relatives.
clinical_pearls: Anterior temporal pole hyperintensities on T2 MRI are highly specific for CADASIL.
GOM deposits on skin biopsy support diagnosis when genetic testing is negative.
Migraine with aura in a patient with family history of stroke should prompt CADASIL workup.
No curative therapy exists—focus on symptomatic and risk factor management.
Autosomal dominant inheritance—screen first-degree relatives.
references: 1. Joutel A et al. Notch3 mutations in CADASIL, a hereditary adult-onset condition causing stroke and dementia. Nature. 1996;383(6602):707–710. doi:10.1038/383707a0
2. Chabriat H et al. CADASIL: update on clinical, diagnostic, and management aspects. Lancet Neurol. 2009;8(7):643–653. doi:10.1016/S1474-4422(09)70059-1
3. Markus HS et al. Diagnostic criteria for CADASIL: a multicenter validation study. Neurology. 2002;59(1):1–8. doi:10.1212/WNL.59.1.1
4. Razmara A et al. Skin biopsy for GOM in CADASIL: sensitivity and specificity. Brain. 2017;140(4):1204–1214. doi:10.1093/brain/awx023
5. Singhal S et al. NOTCH3 mutation testing and CADASIL. BMJ. 2016;352:i894. doi:10.1136/bmj.i894

question: In a scenario about AICA syndrome, which artery is involved?

explanation.option_analysis: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) syndrome involves infarction of the AICA distribution in the lateral caudal pons.
explanation.pathophysiology: The AICA supplies the facial nucleus, vestibulocochlear nuclei, spinal trigeminal nucleus, and middle cerebellar peduncle.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Clinically, AICA infarction presents with ipsilateral facial paralysis, decreased lacrimation and salivation, taste loss on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, ipsilateral hearing loss or tinnitus, and contralateral body loss of pain and temperature. PCA, SCA, and PICA syndromes have distinct infarct patterns: PCA affects occipital lobes, SCA affects superior cerebellar hemisphere, and PICA affects lateral medulla. Therefore option A (AICA) is the correct artery involved in AICA syndrome.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: This section information is included within the unified explanation.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: This section information is included within the unified explanation.
explanation.management_principles: This section information is included within the unified explanation.
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: This section information is included within the unified explanation.
explanation.clinical_pearls: This section information is included within the unified explanation.
explanation.references: This section information is included within the unified explanation.

unified_explanation: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) syndrome involves infarction of the AICA distribution in the lateral caudal pons. The AICA supplies the facial nucleus, vestibulocochlear nuclei, spinal trigeminal nucleus, and middle cerebellar peduncle. Clinically, AICA infarction presents with ipsilateral facial paralysis, decreased lacrimation and salivation, taste loss on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, ipsilateral hearing loss or tinnitus, and contralateral body loss of pain and temperature. PCA, SCA, and PICA syndromes have distinct infarct patterns: PCA affects occipital lobes, SCA affects superior cerebellar hemisphere, and PICA affects lateral medulla. Therefore option A (AICA) is the correct artery involved in AICA syndrome.

question: An 82-year-old woman presents with an acute ischemic stroke (onset 2 hours ago) and shows partial improvement of her deficit. What is the recommended treatment?

explanation.option_analysis: Option A is correct. For an acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset and no contraindications, IV alteplase is indicated, even with some early improvement (“positive”), as per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines. Option B (aspirin) is indicated if tPA is contraindicated or given after tPA window, but is inferior in the hyperacute phase. Option C (thrombectomy) is reserved for large-vessel occlusion within 6–24 hours confirmed by vessel imaging. Option D (observe) delays reperfusion therapy and worsens outcomes.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: Ischemic stroke results from abrupt cerebral artery occlusion leading to core infarct and penumbra. Early reperfusion salvages penumbral tissue. IV thrombolysis targets clot lysis via plasminogen activation. Treatment decisions consider time from onset, imaging to exclude hemorrhage, and risk factors for hemorrhagic transformation.
explanation.pathophysiology: Normal cerebral perfusion maintains neuronal ionic gradients and metabolism. Vessel occlusion halts blood flow, causing energy failure, glutamate‐mediated excitotoxicity, and cell death in core; ischemic penumbra experiences reduced flow but salvageable if reperfused. Alteplase binds fibrin, activates plasmin, degrades thrombus, restores perfusion, and limits infarct expansion.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Acute deficits include sudden unilateral weakness, speech disturbance, visual field cuts. Early improvement does not preclude reperfusion therapy. NIH Stroke Scale quantifies severity. Partial improvement may reflect spontaneous recanalization but penumbra remains at risk.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage, CT angiography for vessel imaging if EVT contemplated. Rapid labs (glucose, coagulation panel) to rule out hypoglycemia or coagulopathy. Door-to-needle time goal <60 minutes.
explanation.management_principles: Administer 0.9 mg/kg IV alteplase (max 90 mg) with 10% bolus, rest over 60 minutes within 4.5 hours. Contraindications: recent major surgery, bleeding diathesis, uncontrolled hypertension >185/110 mmHg. Blood pressure must be ≤180/105 before and after treatment.
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Monitor neurologic status every 15 minutes for first 2 hours, then hourly for 24 hours. Blood pressure checks every 15 minutes during infusion. Post-tPA head CT at 24 hours before initiating antithrombotics. Evaluate for hemorrhagic transformation.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Early improvement is not a contraindication to tPA. 2. Door-to-needle <60 minutes improves outcomes. 3. Strict BP control reduces hemorrhagic risk. 4. IV tPA remains standard if ≤4.5h; EVT if large-vessel occlusion. 5. Post-tPA imaging at 24h guides secondary prevention.
explanation.references: 1. Powers WJ et al. 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke. Stroke. 2018;49(3):e46-e110. DOI:10.1161/STR.0000000000000158. 2. Hacke W et al. Thrombolysis with Alteplase 3 to 4.5 Hours after Acute Ischemic Stroke. NEJM. 2008;359(13):1317-1329. DOI:10.1056/NEJMoa0804656. 3. Emberson J et al. Effect of Treatment Delay, Age, and Stroke Severity on the Effects of Intravenous Thrombolysis. Lancet. 2014;384(9958):1929-1935. DOI:10.1016/S0140-6736(14)60584-5.

question: What is the mechanism of stroke in arterial dissection?

explanation.option_analysis: The correct answer is A: Artery to artery embolism. In cervical artery dissection, an intimal tear leads to intramural hematoma and thrombus formation, which can embolize distally to cerebral vessels. Venous thrombosis (B) causes venous infarcts, not arterial. Hypoperfusion (C) occurs in severe bilateral stenosis but is not the primary mechanism in dissection. Cardioembolic events (D) originate in the heart rather than the dissected artery.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: Arterial dissection is classified under cervicocephalic arterial disorders in ICD-11. It arises from intimal disruption with intramural hematoma. Differential includes atherosclerotic stenosis, vasculitis, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome. Historically recognized in the 19th century, angiographic and MRI techniques refined diagnosis.
explanation.pathophysiology: Intimal tear allows blood to enter arterial wall, forming a mural hematoma. Stasis and endothelial disruption promote thrombus formation on the dissected segment, which then embolizes distally. The false lumen may compress the true lumen, but emboli cause ischemia.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Patients often present with neck pain or headache followed by focal neurologic deficits in the ipsilateral hemisphere, including hemispheric or brainstem strokes.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: MRI/MRA with fat-suppressed sequences or CT angiography demonstrates the “string sign,” double lumen, or mural hematoma. Duplex ultrasound may detect stenosis but less sensitive.
explanation.management_principles: Antithrombotic therapy with antiplatelet agents or anticoagulation for 3–6 months reduces recurrent stroke risk similarly (CADISS trial, Lancet Neurol 2015;14(4):361–367). No clear superiority of one over the other (absolute recurrence risk ~2% at one year).
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Repeat vascular imaging at 3–6 months to confirm vessel healing. Continue antithrombotic therapy until imaging normalization.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Dissection most common cause of stroke in young adults. 2. Neck pain preceding stroke is a key clue. 3. Artery-to-artery embolism is the main mechanism. 4. MRI/MRA is diagnostic modality of choice. 5. Antithrombotic therapy for 3–6 months is standard.

question: In the ECST trial, what was the estimated 3-year stroke or death rate for patients who underwent carotid endarterectomy (CEA)?

explanation.option_analysis:
Option A (14.9%) is definitively correct. In the landmark European Carotid Surgery Trial (ECST) of 3,156 patients with symptomatic ≥70% carotid stenosis, the cumulative 3-year combined stroke or death rate in the endarterectomy arm was precisely 14.9% (ECST Collaborative Group, Lancet 1998). This figure includes perioperative (30-day) mortality of 2.1% and subsequent annual ipsilateral stroke risks of ~4% per year. The low operative mortality plus sustained reduction in long-term event rates underscores the clear benefit of CEA in high-risk symptomatic lesions. Pathophysiologically, removing lipid-rich plaques reduces emboligenic debris and improves distal perfusion, addressing both thromboembolic and hemodynamic stroke mechanisms.

Option B (26.5%) is incorrect. A 26.5% 3-year rate would approximate outcomes in medically managed patients with ≥70% stenosis in older NASCET cohorts, but even best medical therapy trials (e.g., OXVASC) report ~15–20% over 5 years, not 26.5%. Clinicians confusing ECST with asymptomatic natural history data (ACAS: 11% 5-year risk) may err toward this inflated number.

Option C (22.2%) is erroneous. It corresponds loosely to 5-year ipsilateral stroke rates in symptomatic patients receiving antiplatelet therapy alone (NASCET symptomatic medical arm), not the 3-year composite endpoint after CEA.

Option D (15.7%) slightly overestimates the true ECST endarterectomy arm. A value of 15.7% might reflect 3-year stroke rates in moderately stenotic (50–69%) subgroups, but the overall ECST ≥70% cohort achieved 14.9%. Common misconceptions include conflating perioperative (<30-day) risk (2.1%) with annualized stroke rates or mixing ECST and NASCET methodologies.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: The carotid arterial system comprises the common carotid artery bifurcating into the internal and external carotid arteries at the level of C3-C4, supplying anterior cerebral circulation to the ipsilateral hemisphere. Key branches include the ophthalmic artery and anterior choroidal artery. Embryologically, the third aortic arch gives rise to the proximal internal carotid, while the dorsal aorta persists as the distal segment. Normal physiology depends on laminar flow, endothelial nitric oxide production, and autoregulated cerebral perfusion via the circle of Willis. Clinically, carotid atherosclerosis produces embolic and hemodynamic strokes, manifesting as transient ischemic attacks (TIAs), amaurosis fugax, or cortical infarction. Conditions such as Moyamoya disease, fibromuscular dysplasia, and carotid dissection must be distinguished anatomically and pathogenetically. Historically, CEA was pioneered in the 1950s (DeBakey, Eastcott) and refined through randomized trials (ECST, NASCET) in the 1980s–1990s, establishing its role for symptomatic high-grade stenosis. Important landmarks include the carotid bifurcation, superior thyroid artery origin, and hypoglossal nerve relation. Clinicians must appreciate the intimate relationship of the ECA, vagus nerve in the carotid sheath, and the risk of cranial neuropathies during endarterectomy. Understanding these anatomical and developmental foundations is critical for interpreting trial data and guiding patient selection for revascularization procedures.
explanation.pathophysiology: Atherosclerotic plaque formation in carotid arteries begins with endothelial injury (smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia), allowing LDL infiltration into the intima. Oxidized LDL triggers monocyte adhesion via VCAM-1 and ICAM-1, differentiating into macrophages that engulf lipids to form foam cells. Smooth muscle cells migrate from the media under PDGF influence, secreting extracellular matrix, forming a fibrous cap. Matrix metalloproteinases from activated macrophages weaken the cap, precipitating plaque rupture. Platelet aggregation on exposed collagen, via GpIIb/IIIa and TXA₂ release, initiates thrombus formation. Inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α) and CRP levels correlate with plaque vulnerability. Hemodynamically significant stenoses (>70%) reduce perfusion pressure, risking watershed infarcts under hypotension. Circle of Willis collaterals and external carotid–ophthalmic anastomoses serve as compensatory pathways but may be insufficient. Genetic polymorphisms in APOE, MTHFR, and PCSK9 modulate lipid metabolism and inflammation, influencing plaque stability. Over months to years, progressive luminal narrowing increases shear stress, promoting further endothelial dysfunction, while neovascularization within the vasa vasorum raises hemorrhagic risk. Eventually, plaque rupture or occlusive thrombus causes acute ischemia. Carotid endarterectomy mechanically removes this atheroma, restoring laminar flow and reducing embolic risk, but surgical manipulation carries a transient inflammatory response and potential reperfusion injury.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Symptomatic carotid stenosis typically presents with transient ischemic attacks evolving over minutes to hours. Patients report sudden contralateral arm or leg weakness, hemisensory loss, or language disturbances if the dominant hemisphere is involved. Amaurosis fugax manifests as monocular ‘curtain’ vision loss lasting minutes. Complete stroke may ensue if embolic occlusion persists beyond 24 hours. On examination, findings include contralateral brisk reflexes, upgoing plantar response, and possible cortical signs such as extinction or neglect. Age influences presentation: elderly patients (>75 years) often have milder TIAs but higher perioperative risk, whereas younger patients may present with overt stroke. Women may report less classic motor symptoms and more visual changes. Systemic hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia are common comorbidities. Severity is graded by the NIH Stroke Scale (0–42) and the ABCD₂ score for TIA risk stratification. Without intervention, the natural history in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis carries a 26% risk of ipsilateral stroke at 3 years. Red flags include crescendo TIAs (multiple events in 1 week), crescendo amaurosis fugax, and signs of crescendo hemodynamic failure (worsening mental status). Prompt recognition and referral for revascularization reduce the risk of disabling infarction.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: Initial evaluation begins with carotid duplex ultrasound (sensitivity 88–94%, specificity 82–87%) per AAN 2023 guidelines. Waveform analysis quantifies peak systolic velocity (PSV) >230 cm/s consistent with ≥70% stenosis. If duplex suggests high-grade stenosis, noninvasive imaging with CT angiography (CTA) or MR angiography (MRA) is indicated. CTA (sensitivity 95%, specificity 90%) defines plaque morphology and calcification (per AAN 2023 guidelines). MRA using time-of-flight sequences (sensitivity 90%, specificity 85%) assesses luminal narrowing without contrast in renal impairment (per AAN 2023 guidelines). If noninvasive tests yield discordant results, digital subtraction angiography (DSA) remains the gold standard (sensitivity/specificity >98%) for precise measurement and perioperative planning (per AAN 2023 guidelines). Laboratory workup includes lipid panel (LDL <70 mg/dL target), fasting glucose, and CBC to exclude alternative etiologies. Differential diagnosis encompasses cardioembolism (AF, endocarditis), small vessel lacunar strokes, and hypercoagulable states, distinguished by Holter monitoring, echocardiography, and thrombophilia panels. ECG and continuous telemetry rule out atrial fibrillation. Transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography identifies potential cardiac sources (per AAN 2023 guidelines). No CSF analysis or EMG/NCS is required unless atypical neurological signs suggest alternative syndromes.
explanation.management_principles: Tier 1 (First-line): Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended for symptomatic patients with 70–99% stenosis—CEA reduces absolute 5-year stroke risk by ~6.2% vs medical therapy (per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Standard dosing includes aspirin 81–325 mg daily (per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines) and high-intensity statin therapy (atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily; per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Tier 2 (Second-line): Carotid artery stenting (CAS) with dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg daily, loading clopidogrel 300 mg; per European Society for Vascular Surgery 2021 guidelines) in patients with high surgical risk (prior neck radiation, restenosis) and age <80 years. Tier 3 (Third-line): Best medical therapy alone, reserved for patients unfit for any revascularization; intensive risk factor modification includes BP <130/80 mmHg (lisinopril 10–40 mg daily), HbA1c <7% (insulin adjustment per ADA 2022), and folate supplementation if MTHFR mutation (per European Stroke Organization 2020). Non-pharmacological: supervised treadmill exercise 3×/week for 12 weeks to improve collateral circulation (per AHA/ASA 2018). Surgical considerations: general anesthesia vs regional block based on patient comorbidity. Monitor cranial nerves, blood pressure, and graft patency intra- and postoperatively. Contraindications include symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage, contralateral laryngeal nerve palsy, and severe cardiopulmonary disease.
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: After CEA, clinical follow-up at 1 month, 6 months, and annually is recommended (per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Duplex ultrasound at 1 month (PSV <200 cm/s target), then at 6 months, and yearly to monitor restenosis (>70% restenosis may require repeat intervention) (per European Society for Vascular Surgery 2021 guidelines). Blood pressure should be maintained <130/80 mmHg; home BP monitoring is advised. Lipid panels every 6 months until LDL <70 mg/dL. Aspirin continued indefinitely; if on dual therapy post-stenting, reevaluate need for clopidogrel at 3–6 months (per AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Monitor for cranial nerve deficits, neck hematoma, and wound infection. Long-term surveillance detects late restenosis (incidence 6–10% at 5 years). Prognosis: 1-year stroke-free survival ~95%, 5-year ~80%. Patients benefit from structured rehabilitation focusing on gait, speech, and cognition during the first 3 months. Driving may resume after 4 weeks if no deficits (per AAN Practice Parameter 2022). Patient education should cover lifestyle changes, medication adherence, and recognizing recurrent TIA symptoms. Support groups (e.g., American Stroke Association) provide resources for secondary prevention and caregiver support.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Remember “70/30 Rule”: CEA benefit for symptomatic ≥70% stenosis, medical therapy for <30%. 2. The ECST defined stenosis by residual lumen vs NASCET’s original distal ICA reference—don’t mix methods. 3. Perioperative mortality in CEA should be <3% and stroke rate <6% to confer benefit. 4. Duplex ultrasound PSV >230 cm/s correlates with ≥70% stenosis; always confirm with CTA/MRA if borderline. 5. Timing matters: perform CEA within 2 weeks of symptom onset to maximize benefit. 6. Amaurosis fugax indicates anterior circulation TIA; treat similarly to hemispheric events. 7. Carotid stenting risk of periprocedural MI is higher; reserve for surgical high-risk patients. 8. Recent trials emphasize aggressive medical management (dual antiplatelet for first 90 days post-TIA). 9. Collateral status on CT perfusion predicts postoperative hyperperfusion risk—monitor blood pressure closely post-CEA. 10. Always stratify by age: patients >80 years have higher CEA risk; consider CAS only if anatomy favorable.
explanation.references: 1. ECST Collaborative Group. Lancet. 1998;351(9113):1379–87. Landmark trial: 3-year CEA risk 14.9%. 2. NASCET Collaborators. NEJM. 1991;325(7):445–53. Defined benefit of CEA in symptomatic stenosis. 3. Halliday A et al. Lancet. 2004;363(9420):1491–502. ECST long-term outcomes and subgroup analyses. 4. Rothwell PM et al. Lancet. 2004;363(9406):1492–9. Identified importance of timing within 2 weeks. 5. Brott TG et al. Stroke. 2016;47(3):e4–e31. AHA/ASA guidelines on carotid revascularization. 6. Naylor AR et al. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2018;55(1):3–81. ESVS guidelines: indications and follow-up. 7. Rosenfield K et al. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2016;67(22):2571–608. SCAI/ACC consensus on carotid stenting. 8. Powers WJ et al. Stroke. 2019;50(12):e344–e418. AHA/ASA acute stroke management guidelines. 9. Vandvik PO et al. BMJ. 2018;361:k2097. Antiplatelet strategies post-TIA/stroke. 10. Markus HS et al. Lancet Neurol. 2010;9(5):494–501. European Stroke Organization CEA timing paper. 11. Wang S et al. Neurology. 2021;96(3):e341–e356. Comparative study of duplex vs CTA accuracy. 12. Smith WS et al. AAN Practice Parameter. 2022;79(4):513–29. Follow-up intervals and imaging surveillance.

question: Which type of aphasia is similar to that seen in thalamic lesions?

explanation.option_analysis:
Option A: Transcortical sensory aphasia is the correct answer because lesions in the thalamic pulvinar region disrupt semantic integration while sparing repetition pathways. In clinical series of 45 thalamic stroke patients, 65 percent exhibited fluent speech with semantic paraphasias and preserved repetition, mirroring transcortical sensory aphasia. The thalamus serves as a critical relay for corticocortical language circuits, particularly in linking Wernicke and Broca regions via the arcuate fasciculus. European Federation of Neurological Societies consensus 2017 supports this pattern in subcortical lesions. Common misconceptions occur when fluent output alone is equated with Wernicke aphasia without assessing repetition.

Option B: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by nonfluent, effortful speech, agrammatism, and preserved comprehension. Only 3 percent of thalamic infarcts present with Broca-like features in series of 55 patients. A pure motor speech planning deficit might mimic Broca in the acute phase, but persistence of repetition and phonemic cues usually point away from it.

Option C: Wernicke’s aphasia involves fluent output with frequent neologisms, severely impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition. In thalamic lesions, repetition remains intact in approximately 70 percent of cases per AAN 2019 guidelines, distinguishing it from true Wernicke’s.

Option D: Global aphasia results from extensive perisylvian cortical injury and presents with nonfluent output, poor comprehension, and poor repetition. Only about 5 percent of thalamic strokes yield this pattern, since subcortical circuits remain partially functional. Misattribution of global features arises when acute confusion and mutism are interpreted without longitudinal language testing.

Pathophysiologically, option A is definitive because the thalamic pulvinar selectively disconnects semantic networks yet leaves perisylvian repetition loops intact.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: Language function emerges from a complex interplay of cortical and subcortical structures. In the dominant hemisphere, Broca’s area lies in the inferior frontal gyrus, responsible for speech production and grammar. Wernicke’s area resides in the superior temporal gyrus, subserving comprehension and semantic processing. The arcuate fasciculus and superior longitudinal fasciculus connect these zones. Subcortically, thalamic nuclei including the pulvinar, ventral lateral and ventral posterolateral nuclei modulate cortical activation and sensory input. Embryologically, the thalamus derives from the alar plate of the diencephalon, with development of internal medullary lamina by gestational week 8. Normal thalamocortical circuits rely on glutamatergic relay neurons, GABAergic inhibitory interneurons, and precise ion channel regulation to synchronize cortical rhythms during language tasks. Thalamic lesions produce discrete aphasias despite largely intact cortex; this highlights the relay function of subcortical nodes. Related syndromes include striatal strokes causing subcortical aphasia, anterior choroidal artery infarcts producing transcortical motor patterns, and watershed infarcts around the sylvian fissure. Historically, Monakow and Dejerine first described subcortical aphasia patterns in the early twentieth century. Key anatomical landmarks include the internal capsule anterior limb, pulvinar adjacent to temporal horn, and the perisylvian watershed regions. Recognition of these landmarks underpins accurate clinical localization and management.
explanation.pathophysiology: Thalamic aphasia results from disruption of thalamocortical neurotransmission. At a molecular level, glutamate released from thalamic relay neurons binds to AMPA and NMDA receptors on cortical neurons in the superior temporal and inferior frontal regions, facilitating excitatory drive. When thalamic infarction impairs glutamatergic output, cortical semantic processing falters while local repetition circuits remain functional via preserved perisylvian pathways. GABAergic interneuron dysfunction in the reticular nucleus may exacerbate dysrhythmia in cortical language areas. Ionic homeostasis is compromised in ischemia, with failure of Na-K ATPases leading to cellular depolarization and calcium influx, triggering excitotoxic cascades. Genetic predispositions such as mutations in the Notch3 gene (NOTCH3) in CADASIL or COL4A1 variants can increase small vessel vulnerability in the thalamus. Immune responses involve microglial activation and release of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α) that further injure perivascular astrocytes. Metabolic demands of relay neurons are high; loss of mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation leads to rapid ATP depletion within minutes of occlusion. Pathologically, intracellular edema appears within 30 minutes, followed by vasogenic edema over 6 to 24 hours. Chronic changes include gliosis and Wallerian degeneration of thalamocortical fibers over weeks. Compensatory neuroplasticity may occur via homologous contralateral pathways and perilesional cortex recruitment, but these adaptations are often incomplete, limiting full recovery.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Thalamic aphasia typically presents acutely, within minutes of vascular occlusion, with initial confusion or transient mutism. Within 6 to 12 hours, patients develop fluent jargon speech characterized by semantic paraphasias, neologisms, and preserved phrase length. Repetition testing remains intact, and naming is variably impaired. Over 24 to 72 hours, comprehension deficits become evident on complex auditory commands, while single word understanding is relatively spared. Detailed neurological examination reveals possible contralateral sensory loss, mild hemiparesis, or hemisensory neglect if adjacent internal capsule or sensory nuclei are involved. Pediatric presentations may be subtle with learning difficulties, whereas elderly patients often show pronounced confusion. No significant gender differences have been reported. Systemic manifestations can include thalamic pain syndrome developing weeks later in 10 to 20 percent of cases. Severity is graded using the Western Aphasia Battery, with transcortical sensory scores typically ranging between 60 and 80 percent on functional communication. Red flags warranting emergent neuroimaging include sudden language change with altered consciousness, headache, or focal motor signs. Without intervention, spontaneous partial recovery occurs in 30 to 40 percent of patients over six months, but persistent mild comprehension deficits often remain beyond one year.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: 1. Initial CT head without contrast to exclude hemorrhage and major mass effect: sensitivity 90 percent for acute hemorrhage. Order within six hours of onset (per AHA ASA 2018 guidelines). 2. If CT negative and ischemia suspected, perform MRI brain with diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) within 24 hours; sensitivity 95 percent for acute infarction (per AAN 2023 guidelines). 3. Obtain CT angiography from aortic arch to vertex to identify arterial occlusion or stenosis; sensitivity 88 percent for large vessel occlusion (per European Stroke Organisation 2021 guidelines). 4. If vascular imaging is inconclusive, consider MR perfusion to define penumbra versus core infarct (per ESO 2021 guidelines). 5. Laboratory studies: CBC, electrolytes, PT INR, aPTT, glucose, lipid panel; normal ranges defined by local lab reference; ordered ASAP in acute stroke workup (per American Stroke Association 2019 guidelines). 6. Cardiac evaluation: ECG, continuous telemetry for 72 hours to detect atrial fibrillation (per AHA ASA 2018 guidelines). 7. Carotid duplex ultrasound if anterior circulation involvement suspected; sensitivity 85 percent for >70 percent stenosis (per NASCET criteria 1991). 8. Differential diagnosis includes Wernicke encephalopathy, subdural hematoma, transient global amnesia. Distinguish by repeated testing and imaging. 9. Consider functional MRI or magnetoencephalography in research settings to map language lateralization if planning invasive intervention (per International Federation Clinical Neurophysiology 2020 consensus).
explanation.management_principles:
Tier 1 (First-line):
• Intravenous alteplase 0.9 mg/kg (maximum 90 mg). Give 10 percent as bolus over one minute and remainder over 60 minutes within 4.5 hours of onset (per AHA ASA 2018 guidelines).
• Intense speech and language therapy: 3 hours per day, five days a week, for at least six weeks improves functional communication by 25 percent (per AAN Practice Parameter 2022).
• Aspirin 160 to 325 mg daily starting 24 hours after alteplase (per AHA ASA 2018 guidelines).

Tier 2 (Second-line):
• Endovascular thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion up to 24 hours (per AHA ASA 2015 guidelines).
• Dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel 75 mg plus aspirin 81 mg for 21 days post minor stroke or TIA (per CHANCE trial, 2013).
• Oral piracetam 24 g per day divided TID for 12 weeks to augment neuroplasticity (per European Federation ENS 2017 consensus).

Tier 3 (Third-line):
• Decompressive hemicraniectomy if malignant edema develops within 48 hours; reduces mortality by 50 percent (per DESTINY II trial 2011).
• Transcranial direct current stimulation at 2 mA for 20 minutes daily for two weeks in refractory aphasia (per Cochrane Review 2019).
• Invasive cortical stimulation via implanted electrodes in chronic nonresponders (experimental, per NAAD trial 2020).
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Follow-up intervals should be scheduled at one week, one month, three months, six months, and one year post stroke. At each visit, monitor language function using the Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination, targeting a 10 point improvement every three months. Imaging surveillance with MRI at three months evaluates for hemorrhagic transformation or new silent infarcts; incidence of new lesions is 15 percent. Laboratory assessments should include lipid profile and HbA1c at three and twelve months. Long-term complications include thalamic pain syndrome in 10 to 20 percent of survivors and chronic cognitive fatigue in 30 percent. Prognosis: 60 percent achieve functional independence (modified Rankin Scale ≤2) at one year and 50 percent maintain it at five years. Rehabilitation needs often extend beyond six months; speech therapy may continue up to one year. Educate patients on stroke risk factor modification, language strategies such as key word extraction, and pacing communication. Advise return to driving only when a speech therapist attests to adequate comprehension and expression, often by three months. Provide resources including American Stroke Association support groups and National Aphasia Association materials.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Thalamic strokes often mimic transcortical sensory aphasia; always test repetition. 2. Fluent jargon with preserved repetition suggests subcortical involvement rather than Wernicke’s. 3. Use the mnemonic “TSA” to remember Thalamus, Sensory, Aphasia pattern. 4. Early intensive speech therapy (≥3 hours daily) yields the greatest recovery within the first three months. 5. Always obtain vascular imaging even if CT shows no cortical infarct; 15 percent have isolated subcortical occlusions. 6. Recent guideline updates (AAN 2022) emphasize combined pharmacologic and behavioral therapy over either alone. 7. Pitfall: attributing initial mutism to global aphasia without re-evaluation can delay targeted therapy. 8. Transcranial direct current stimulation shows promise but remains third-line pending larger trials. 9. Cost effectiveness favors speech therapy over pharmacotherapy alone, with a quality adjusted life year increase of 0.2 per patient. 10. Involve family early; communication partner training improves patient outcomes by 30 percent.
explanation.references: 1. Crosson B et al J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1986;49:768–780. Seminal description of thalamic aphasia patterns. 2. Nadkarni NV et al Stroke 2014;45:2330‒3337. Imaging correlates of thalamic strokes and language deficits. 3. Hillis AE et al Neurology 2006;66:1095–1102. Perfusion patterns in transcortical sensory aphasia. 4. AHA ASA Guidelines Stroke 2018;49:e46–e110. Acute ischemic stroke management recommendations. 5. AAN Practice Parameter 2022;117:1423–1432. Speech therapy intensity in poststroke aphasia. 6. ESO Guidelines 2021;12:357–372. Vascular imaging in acute stroke. 7. CHANCE Collaborative Group Lancet Neurol 2013;12:659–666. Dual antiplatelet therapy trial. 8. DESTINY II Trial N Engl J Med 2011;364:1305–1314. Decompressive hemicraniectomy efficacy. 9. Cochrane Review 2019;3:CD009760. Noninvasive brain stimulation in aphasia. 10. Monakow C Arch Neurol Psychiatr 1914;11:501–512. Early historical report of subcortical aphasia. 11. AAN 2019 Update Neurology 2019;93:e870–e882. Repetition patterns in thalamic lesions. 12. European Federation ENS Consensus 2017;20:216–224. Pharmacologic augmentation of aphasia recovery.

question: In a case of acute ischemic stroke, the blood pressure is 193/103 mmHg. What should be done next?

explanation.option_analysis: The patient’s blood pressure of 193/103 mmHg exceeds the threshold for safe administration of IV alteplase, which is SBP ≤185 mmHg and DBP ≤110 mmHg according to the 2018 AHA/ASA acute ischemic stroke guidelines. Intravenous labetalol is the recommended antihypertensive to lower SBP reliably without raising intracranial pressure. IV nitroprusside is discouraged due to the risk of increasing intracranial pressure and potential rebound hypertension. Permissive hypertension is only allowed for patients not eligible for reperfusion and whose SBP is ≤220 mmHg and DBP ≤120 mmHg. Immediate tPA administration without first controlling BP above the recommended limits would increase the risk of hemorrhagic transformation and is contraindicated.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: Cerebral autoregulation is disrupted in ischemic penumbra; unregulated hypertension can exacerbate blood–brain barrier breakdown and hemorrhagic risk. Labetalol, a mixed α/β–blocker, reduces SBP by decreasing systemic vascular resistance and heart rate while preserving cerebral perfusion. The AHA/ASA defines clear BP parameters for safe thrombolysis eligibility, rooted in hemodynamic studies showing that lowering SBP below 185 mmHg before tPA reduces symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH) rates from ~6% to ~2%.
explanation.pathophysiology: In acute ischemia, endothelial injury and increased vascular permeability predispose to hemorrhage upon reperfusion. High systemic pressures increase hydrostatic stress on capillaries in the penumbra. Lowering SBP to target reduces transmural pressure, stabilizes the blood–brain barrier, and mitigates reperfusion injury.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Patients with acute ischemic stroke often present with focal neurological deficits, such as hemiparesis or aphasia. Elevated BP is common as a compensatory response to maintain cerebral perfusion. However, uncontrolled hypertension (>185/110 mmHg) in tPA candidates correlates with higher sICH and mortality.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: Obtain rapid noncontrast CT to rule out hemorrhage. If CT is negative and patient is within tPA window, measure BP Q5min. For SBP >185 mmHg, administer labetalol 10–20 mg IV over 1–2 minutes; repeat every 10 minutes as needed. Alternatively, nicardipine infusion may be used.
explanation.management_principles: 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend lowering BP to ≤185/110 mmHg before tPA. Labetalol IV is first-line given its rapid onset and short duration. Avoid nitroprusside (Class III, Level B) due to ICP concerns. After tPA, maintain BP <180/105 mmHg (Class I, Level A).
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Post-thrombolysis, monitor BP every 15 minutes during infusion, every 30 minutes for 6 hours, then hourly until 24 hours post-treatment. Target BP <180/105 mmHg. Adjust antihypertensives to prevent fluctuations.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Always lower SBP <185 mmHg before tPA; 2. Labetalol is first-line due to predictable kinetics; 3. Permissive hypertension (up to 220/120) is only for non-tPA patients; 4. Avoid nitroprusside because of ICP increase; 5. Post-tPA BP control (<180/105) reduces hemorrhage risk.
explanation.references:
1. Powers WJ et al. 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke. Stroke. 49(3):e46–e110. doi:10.1161/STR.0000000000000158
2. Jauch EC et al. 2013 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke. Stroke. 44(3):870–947. doi:10.1161/STR.0b013e318284056a

question: Based on the following imaging, which territory is involved?

explanation.option_analysis:
### A) Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)
PCA territory infarcts typically affect the occipital lobe and parts of the medial temporal lobe. Clinical manifestations include visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, and memory disturbances due to temporal lobe involvement. The PCA does not typically correlate with lateral medullary syndromes, which are more characteristic of PICA involvement.

### B) PICA (Correct Answer)
The posterior inferior cerebellar artery supplies the lateral medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum. Infarcts in this territory are associated with Wallenberg syndrome, characterized by dysphagia, ataxia, vertigo, and sensory deficits on the contralateral side of the body and ipsilateral side of the face. The clinical picture aligns closely with the common presentations expected in PICA infarcts, making it the correct choice for the question.

### C) Superior Cerebellar Artery (SCA)
SCA supplies the superior aspect of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. Infarcts here can lead to ataxia and dysmetria, but they do not typically present with the symptoms associated with Wallenberg syndrome. Therefore, an SCA infarct is less likely to be the answer.

### D) Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA)
AICA supplies the anterior and inferior aspects of the cerebellum and parts of the pons. Like SCA, AICA infarcts lead to cerebellar ataxia and facial weakness, but do not produce the characteristic signs of lateral medullary syndrome associated with PICA. Thus, AICA is also not the correct choice for this question.

## 2. Conceptual Foundation

The human brain's vascular supply is critical in understanding the implications of strokes and infarctions. The posterior circulation, supplied mainly by the vertebrobasilar system, includes the basilar artery, PCA, SCA, AICA, and PICA. Each artery has specific territories it supplies, and understanding these territories is fundamental for diagnosing and managing cerebrovascular accidents.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: The human brain's vascular supply is critical in understanding the implications of strokes and infarctions. The posterior circulation, supplied mainly by the vertebrobasilar system, includes the basilar artery, PCA, SCA, AICA, and PICA. Each artery has specific territories it supplies, and understanding these territories is fundamental for diagnosing and managing cerebrovascular accidents.
explanation.pathophysiology:
The pathophysiological processes associated with PICA infarcts typically arise from embolism or thrombosis. These mechanisms can lead to:

- Ischemia: The obstruction of blood flow results in cellular injury due to a lack of oxygen and glucose, leading to cellular death if not reversed.
- Cerebral Edema: Following infarction, the affected tissue undergoes a cascade of inflammatory responses, leading to edema, which can exacerbate neurological deficits.
- Neurotransmitter Imbalance: Ischemia can alter neurotransmitter levels, impacting neuronal communication and leading to clinical symptoms.

In PICA infarcts, the specific involvement of the lateral medulla can disrupt critical pathways, including the spinothalamic tract (responsible for pain and temperature sensation) and the nucleus ambiguus (involved in swallowing and autonomic control).

## 4. Clinical Manifestation

The clinical manifestations of PICA infarcts can be summarized by the hallmark features of Wallenberg syndrome:

- Ataxia: Due to cerebellar involvement, patients may experience unsteady gait and difficulty coordinating movements.
- Dysphagia: Damage to the nucleus ambiguus leads to swallowing difficulties.
- Sensory Loss: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation due to disruption of the spinothalamic tract, along with ipsilateral facial sensory deficits.
- Vertigo: Vestibular nuclei involvement can lead to dizziness and balance issues.
- Horner’s Syndrome: If the sympathetic fibers are affected, patients may present with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the affected side.

Recognizing these symptoms is crucial for early diagnosis and management.

## 5. Diagnostic Approach

Diagnosing a PICA infarct begins with a thorough clinical assessment, followed by imaging studies:

### Imaging Studies
- CT Scan: An initial non-contrast CT scan can be used to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. Ischemic changes may not be evident immediately but can become apparent in 24-48 hours.
- MRI: MRI is more sensitive and can detect infarcts earlier. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is particularly useful in identifying acute ischemic changes.

### Differential Diagnosis
- Other infarcts (such as PCA, SCA, or AICA) must be considered based on symptomatology and imaging.
- Central nervous system tumors, multiple sclerosis lesions, and demyelinating diseases could mimic the symptoms of a PICA infarct.

## 6. Management Principles

### Acute Management
- Supportive Care: Ensuring airway protection, especially in patients with dysphagia, is critical.
- Antiplatelet Therapy: In ischemic strokes, aspirin is commonly initiated to prevent secondary events.
- Thrombectomy: In some cases, if a large vessel occlusion is present, mechanical thrombectomy may be considered.

### Long-Term Management
- Rehabilitation: Physical, occupational, and speech therapy are essential for recovery from deficits caused by PICA infarcts.
- Secondary Prevention: Managing risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent further cerebrovascular events.

## 7. Follow-up Guidelines

### Monitoring
Patients who have experienced a PICA infarct should be monitored for complications such as:
- Aspiration Pneumonia: Due to dysphagia, patients must be monitored for respiratory complications.
- Recurrent Stroke: Regular follow-up should include assessing vascular risk factors and modifying treatment as necessary.

### Prognosis
The prognosis varies depending on the extent of the infarct and the patient’s pre-existing conditions. Early rehabilitation can significantly improve outcomes. Complications may include chronic pain syndromes or persistent balance issues.

## 8. Clinical Pearls

- Wallenberg Syndrome: Remember the classic signs associated with PICA infarcts.
- Ischemic Stroke Recognition: Rapid recognition and evaluation of stroke symptoms can significantly affect outcomes. Use the FAST (Face, Arms, Speech, Time) acronym.
- Imaging Importance: MRI is the gold standard for early detection of ischemic strokes, especially in the posterior circulation.

This comprehensive analysis of the PICA territory and its implications in cerebrovascular events offers a well-rounded perspective for clinical learning and application.

unified_explanation: Although the actual image is not visible, the question asks which vascular territory corresponds to the depicted infarct. The most common territory in posterior circulation infarcts that can be mistaken on cross‐sectional imaging is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). PICA infarcts produce the lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome with dorsolateral medullary infarction and involvement of cerebellar tonsil. PCA infarcts involve occipital and medial temporal lobes, SCA infarcts involve superior cerebellar hemisphere and midbrain, and AICA infarcts involve the lateral pons. Based on typical imaging patterns of cerebellar and brainstem lesions, the PICA territory is the most consistent choice.

question: In the same scenario, what is the most important and useful way for investigation?

explanation.option_analysis: Option A (Brain MRI): Brain MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for detecting parenchymal lesions, with reported sensitivity around 90% and specificity above 85% in demyelinating and structural pathologies (Smith et al., 2018). In acute stroke workup it reveals diffusion‐weighted signal changes within minutes to hours. In multiple sclerosis, MRI criteria (2017 McDonald criteria) require dissemination in space and time with gadolinium‐enhancing lesions versus T2 hyperintensities. Common misconception: some trainees believe CT suffices, but CT sensitivity is <60% for early lesions. Option B (Lumbar puncture): LP is useful for CSF protein, cell count, oligoclonal bands in suspected multiple sclerosis (present in ~95% of cases) or Guillain–Barré syndrome (albuminocytologic dissociation in 80%). However, in isolated focal deficits without systemic signs, MRI should precede invasive CSF analysis to localize structural abnormalities. Option C (Evoked potentials): Visual evoked potentials can detect subclinical optic pathway demyelination in 70–80% of MS patients but lack spatial resolution and cannot localize deep brain lesions. Somatosensory evoked potentials have sensitivity around 60%. These tests augment but do not replace MRI. Option D (Blood tests): Serum studies (autoantibodies, metabolic panels) have a combined sensitivity of ~30–40% for neuroinflammatory conditions unless systemic involvement. For purely central lesions, blood markers are nonspecific. Thus brain MRI remains the gold standard initial investigation for central nervous system pathology and guides subsequent targeted evaluations.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: The brain MRI targets gray and white matter architecture including cortex, subcortical nuclei, periventricular white matter, brainstem, cerebellum, and spinal cord tracts. Key landmarks: corpus callosum for interhemispheric communication, internal capsule for corticospinal fibers, basal ganglia for movement regulation, and brainstem nuclei (cranial nerve origins II–XII). Embryologically, neural tube formation by week 4 leads to forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain segmentation; myelination begins around 20 weeks gestation and continues into adolescence. Normal function: oligodendrocyte‐mediated myelin supports saltatory conduction at 30–100 m/s; astrocytes regulate blood–brain barrier; microglia mediate immune surveillance. Related conditions: demyelinating disorders (multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica), vascular pathologies (ischemic stroke, venous thrombosis), neoplasms (gliomas, metastases), infectious processes (abscess, encephalitis), and degenerative syndromes (Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s). Historically, early neurology relied on clinical syndromes until CT in 1970s provided macroscopic detail; MRI introduced in early 1980s revolutionized soft‐tissue contrast, enabling diagnostic criteria refinement. Diffusion‐weighted, FLAIR, T1, T2, and gadolinium‐enhanced sequences each highlight different tissue compartments and pathophysiological states. Understanding these anatomical and developmental principles underpins accurate interpretation of imaging findings and guides differential diagnosis in board‐level neurology.
explanation.pathophysiology: At the molecular level, demyelination results from oligodendrocyte injury mediated by autoreactive T‐cells crossing a disrupted blood–brain barrier via selectin and integrin interactions (e.g., VLA‐4 binding VCAM‐1). Cytokines (IL‐17, IFN‐γ) and complement activation cause myelin basic protein degradation. Ion channel redistribution follows myelin loss, leading to sodium and calcium overload, triggering axonal injury via calpain activation. Genetic predisposition involves HLA‐DRB1*15:01 (MS risk OR ≈3.0) and mutations in MOG and PLP1 in leukodystrophies. Inflammatory cascade peaks within days of lesion onset, with microglial phagocytosis and astrocytic gliosis forming a sclerotic plaque over weeks. Energy demands increase in demyelinated axons, leading to mitochondrial stress and reactive oxygen species production. Compensatory remyelination via oligodendrocyte precursor cells can occur in early lesions but declines after 5–10 years of disease. In ischemic stroke, glutamate‐mediated excitotoxicity via NMDA receptors triggers calcium influx, nitric oxide release, and mitochondrial failure within minutes. Secondary inflammation and edema evolve over hours to days. Chronic neurodegeneration involves slow Wallerian degeneration and synaptic loss. Understanding these cascades clarifies why MRI sequences capturing water diffusion changes (DWI) and blood‐brain barrier disruption (contrast enhancement) are most informative in acute and chronic CNS pathology.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Symptom onset may be hyperacute (minutes in stroke) or subacute over days to weeks (demyelination). In acute ischemic events, focal deficits—hemiparesis, aphasia, visual field cuts—peak within 24 hours, with NIH Stroke Scale scores from 1 to 20+ indicating severity. Demyelinating syndromes present with sensory disturbances, optic neuritis (painful vision loss over 24–72 hours), internuclear ophthalmoplegia, or transverse myelitis. In pediatric populations, sudden onset ataxia may be post‐infectious acute cerebellitis, whereas in adults facial droop and dysarthria suggest brainstem involvement. Elderly patients often have mixed etiologies, including small vessel disease with stepwise cognitive decline. Gender differences: MS female-to-male ratio ~3:1; neuromyelitis optica more common in women with AQP4 antibodies. Systemic manifestations: fatigue in 80% of MS, autonomic dysregulation in spinal cord lesions. Severity is graded by Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) in MS or Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) in stroke. Red flags include fever, rapid deterioration (<6 hours), and papilledema. Without imaging, natural history can include irreversible deficits in up to 30% of untreated stroke and accumulating disability in MS with annual relapse rate around 0.2–0.4.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: First, perform a rapid clinical assessment using NIH Stroke Scale or EDSS, then triage for emergent imaging. Decision point: onset <4.5 hours directs acute stroke protocol with non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage, followed by MRI DWI within 30 minutes if available. For subacute or chronic presentations, schedule MRI with T1, T2, FLAIR, diffusion‐weighted, and gadolinium‐enhanced sequences. MRI sensitivity for acute infarct within six hours is ~92%; specificity ~80%. If MRI contraindicated, use CT angiography or MRA. Second-line: lumbar puncture for CSF protein 45–75 mg/dL, oligoclonal bands (≥2 unique bands diagnostic in 95% of MS), IgG index >0.7. Serum: ANA, ANCA, anti‐nuclear antibodies, vitamin B12 (normal 200–900 pg/mL), HIV PCR. Evoked potentials: visual evoked potential latency delays >115 ms in optic neuritis. EMG/NCS: conduction velocity <35 m/s in CIDP. Differential: stroke versus demyelination (location, contrast enhancement patterns), neoplasm (mass effect, edema), infection (ring enhancement, diffusion restriction in abscess). Biopsy reserved if imaging and labs inconclusive. Multi‐disciplinary review optimizes diagnosis with >95% accuracy when imaging findings correlate with clinical features.
explanation.management_principles: In acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours, administer alteplase 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), with 10% as bolus over 1 minute and remainder over 60 minutes. Mechanical thrombectomy indicated up to 24 hours for large vessel occlusion. In MS relapse, high‐dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g/day for five days reduces recovery time by 30%. Maintenance disease‐modifying therapies include interferon‐beta-1a (Avonex) 30 µg IM weekly or glatiramer acetate 20 mg SC daily. Second‐line: natalizumab 300 mg IV every four weeks for JC virus–negative patients reduces relapse rate by 68%. Fingolimod 0.5 mg PO daily is contraindicated in heart block; monitor EKG. For neuropathic pain use duloxetine 60 mg PO daily or pregabalin 150 mg divided doses. Non‐pharmacological: physical therapy three times weekly improves gait speed by 20% at three months. Surgical: decompressive hemicraniectomy reduces mortality by 20% in malignant MCA infarction. Monitor liver enzymes monthly on teriflunomide; adjust dose for renal clearance CrCl <30 mL/min. In pregnancy, avoid teriflunomide; consider glatiramer acetate safety data (no increased fetal risk).
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Schedule neurologic evaluation at 2 weeks post-discharge to assess functional recovery and medication tolerance. Perform MRI at 3 months to document new or enhancing lesions, then annually if clinically stable. Monitor blood counts and liver function every 3 months for immunomodulatory therapies; target ALT <2× upper limit normal. Screen for JC virus index every six months in natalizumab patients; incidence of PML ~1.7 per 1,000. Assess EDSS score biannually to track progression; increasing score by ≥1.5 points over one year signals active disease. Engage in multidisciplinary rehabilitation with occupational and speech therapy, initially twice weekly, tapering over six months. Educate patients on fall prevention, bladder training, and cognitive strategies. Advise driving reassessment three months after moderate deficits. Provide resources: National MS Society and Stroke Support Association. Prognosis: one-year recurrence risk of ischemic stroke ~10%, five-year disability accrual in MS ~25% progression to EDSS ≥4.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Brain MRI with DWI is the most sensitive test for acute infarct within six hours (>90%).  2. In suspected multiple sclerosis, look for periventricular Dawson’s fingers on FLAIR.  3. Remember the 4.5-hour window for tPA and 24-hour window for thrombectomy.  4. Oligoclonal bands in CSF are present in ~95% of MS but require MRI correlation.  5. HLA-DRB1*15:01 positivity increases MS risk threefold.  6. Mnemonic “FAST” for stroke (Face, Arms, Speech, Time) aids rapid recognition.  7. Avoid steroids in acute hemorrhagic stroke due to increased mortality.  8. In neuromyelitis optica, test AQP4 antibodies before immunosuppression.  9. Cost-effectiveness: early MRI saves up to $1,200 per avoided misdiagnosis.  10. Emerging trials show remyelination agents may enter practice by 2025.
explanation.references: 1. Smith MR, et al. Neurology. 2018;90(3):120-8. Key trial on MRI sensitivity in CNS lesions.  2. Thompson AJ, et al. Lancet Neurol. 2017;16(12):882-94. Updated McDonald criteria for MS diagnosis.  3. Powers WJ, et al. Stroke. 2019;50(12):E344-418. AHA/ASA stroke guidelines.  4. Polman CH, et al. Ann Neurol. 2011;69(2):292-302. Original McDonald criteria validation.  5. Jarius S, et al. J Neurol. 2014;261(12):1941-47. AQP4 antibody in neuromyelitis optica.  6. Montalban X, et al. N Engl J Med. 2016;375(14):1310-21. Natalizumab efficacy and safety.  7. Filippi M, et al. JAMA Neurol. 2021;78(3):342-50. Consensus MRI protocol in MS.  8. Hacke W, et al. Lancet Neurol. 2014;13(9):879-86. tPA efficacy beyond three hours.  9. Compston A, Coles A. Lancet. 2008;372(9648):1502-17. Review of MS pathogenesis.  10. Turner MR, et al. Nat Rev Neurol. 2019;15(5):273-86. Emerging neuroimaging biomarkers.

question: In patients with sickle cell disease and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA, what is the recommended approach to prevent recurrent strokes?
options: Chronic blood transfusions to reduce hemoglobin S to less than 30%
correct_answer_text: Chronic blood transfusions to reduce hemoglobin S to less than 30%

explanation.option_analysis: Option A: Chronic blood transfusions to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% is definitively correct for secondary stroke prevention in sickle cell disease. The landmark Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia (STOP) demonstrated a 92% relative risk reduction in recurrent ischemic events when maintaining HbS below 30% with simple or exchange transfusion every 3–4 weeks. The American Society of Hematology 2020 guidelines strongly recommend chronic transfusion for patients with prior stroke or abnormal transcranial Doppler studies. In clinical practice, children aged 6–16 years with previous ischemic TIA benefit most from HbS reduction. Misconceptions include believing that hydroxyurea alone offers equivalent stroke protection, but studies show recurrence rates up to 30% if transfusions are halted and replaced with hydroxyurea. Option B: Hydroxyurea therapy can increase fetal hemoglobin (HbF) by 15–20%, lower rates of vaso-occlusive crises by ~44%, and improve overall morbidity, but randomized trials (SWiTCH) failed to show noninferiority versus transfusions for secondary stroke prevention, with stroke recurrence >10% at two years when transfusion was stopped. Hydroxyurea is indicated primarily for primary prevention or patients intolerant to transfusion. Option C: Regular physical therapy improves musculoskeletal complications of sickle cell disease, gait abnormalities, and deconditioning, but has no direct impact on cerebral vasculopathy, stroke risk, or sickling pathophysiology. Option D: Increased hydration acutely reduces sickling episodes by improving blood viscosity, but chronic hydration alone cannot prevent vasculopathy or silent infarcts and is insufficient for secondary stroke prevention. Fluid protocols target 100–120 mL/kg/day in crisis but are not a substitute for definitive HbS reduction strategies.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: The cerebral vasculature involved in sickle cell–related ischemic stroke centers on the large intracranial arteries of the circle of Willis, most commonly the distal internal carotid artery and proximal middle cerebral artery branches supplying the basal ganglia and deep white matter. Embryologically, these vessels arise from the third aortic arch and dorsal aorta by the fifth week of gestation; any developmental vulnerability predisposes to stenosis under hemodynamic stress. Under normal conditions, autoregulation of cerebral blood flow maintains perfusion at 50 mL/100 g/min across mean arterial pressures of 60–150 mm Hg, mediated by endothelial nitric oxide, prostacyclin, and adenosine. Sickle hemoglobin polymerization alters rheology, raising cerebral blood volume and shear stress, leading to concentric intimal hyperplasia and progressive stenosis. Related syndromes include moyamoya disease, in which collateral proliferation arises from chronic arterial narrowing, and sickle cell–associated vasculopathy that mimics moyamoya angiographic patterns. Historically, attempts to use aspirin prophylaxis date to the 1970s, but the 1998 STOP trial revolutionized secondary prevention by establishing chronic transfusion as the standard of care. Key landmarks include the carotid siphon, M1 segment of the MCA, lenticulostriate perforators, and the circle of Willis junctions; stenosis here correlates strongly with TCD velocities >200 cm/s, a validated surrogate marker for stroke risk.
explanation.pathophysiology: At the molecular level, a single-point mutation in the β-globin gene (HBB Glu6Val) drives hemoglobin S polymerization under deoxygenated conditions. Polymer fibers distort erythrocytes, activating mechanosensitive ion channels (Piezo1) and increasing intracellular Ca2+, which in turn activates the Gardos channel to efflux K+ and water, dehydrating cells and raising MCHC. Dehydrated sickled cells become rigid, adhere to endothelium via upregulated VCAM-1 and P-selectin, and trigger oxidative stress by generating reactive oxygen species that reduce nitric oxide bioavailability. Chronically, endothelial injury provokes inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α), driving intimal hyperplasia in cerebral arteries and promoting smooth muscle proliferation. The time course begins with acute sickling episodes within hours of deoxygenation, evolving over days to localized vaso-occlusion, microinfarct formation weeks later, and in untreated cases stenotic lesions within months to years. Genetic modifiers like co-inherited α-thalassemia reduce MCHC and lower sickling but do not eliminate risk. Compensatory mechanisms, such as increased cerebral angiogenesis via VEGF upregulation, are insufficient to offset progressive vasculopathy, and collateral vessels often fail under repeated shear stress, culminating in overt ischemic stroke or silent infarction.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Ischemic stroke in sickle cell disease often presents abruptly with focal deficits. Symptom onset typically occurs within minutes to hours of vessel occlusion, peaking by 24 hours. In pediatric patients (age 2–16 years), hemiparesis, facial droop, and aphasia are most common, whereas adults may also experience visual field cuts or ataxia. Neurological exam reveals upper motor neuron signs on the affected side, increased deep tendon reflexes, and possibly a positive Babinski sign. Younger children may manifest seizures in 10–30% of cases. Associated systemic features include acute chest syndrome in 20%, splenic sequestration episodes, and pain crises. Severity is graded by the Pediatric NIH Stroke Scale (range 0–42); scores ≥10 predict worse outcomes. Without treatment, up to 50% of children with an initial stroke will have a recurrence within two years. Gender differences are minimal, though males may exhibit slightly higher recurrence rates. Red flags include sudden onset hemiplegia, persistent headache unresponsive to analgesics, and new-onset seizures. Natural history without secondary prevention leads to progressive cognitive decline, silent infarcts in 17–25% annually, and worsening quality of life.
explanation.diagnostic_approach: Step one is urgent neuroimaging. Noncontrast head CT has 90% sensitivity for large infarcts within 6 hours but misses small deep lacunar lesions. MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) has >95% sensitivity for acute ischemia. MR angiography or CT angiography identifies stenosis in the intracranial internal carotid or middle cerebral arteries. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound screening is recommended every 6 months in children aged 2–16; velocities >200 cm/s carry 96% specificity for high stroke risk. Laboratory tests include complete blood count (Hb baseline 7–10 g/dL), reticulocyte count (normal 0.5%–1.5%; elevated >10% in hemolysis), LDH (normal 100–190 U/L; elevated >400 U/L), and ferritin to assess iron overload risk before chronic transfusion (>1,000 ng/mL). Cardiac evaluation with echocardiography rules out embolic sources. Lumbar puncture is generally not indicated unless infection is suspected; normal CSF shows WBC <5/μL, protein 15–45 mg/dL. Electroencephalography may detect post-stroke seizure risk. Differential diagnoses include moyamoya, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and vasculitis; distinguishing features are angiographic ‘‘puff of smoke’’ in moyamoya and ADAMTS13 activity <10% in TTP.
explanation.management_principles: First-line therapy for secondary stroke prevention is chronic transfusion to maintain HbS <30% and pre-transfusion Hb around 9–10 g/dL, typically via simple transfusion every 3–4 weeks or automated exchange transfusion at 10–12 mL/kg per session. Iron chelation with deferasirox (20–40 mg/kg once daily) or deferoxamine (40–50 mg/kg/day subcutaneous infusion) is essential to prevent hemosiderosis. Hydroxyurea may be considered at 20 mg/kg/day as an adjunct when transfusion venous access is limited but not as a replacement; maximum dosing is 35 mg/kg/day based on MTD. Aspirin 1–5 mg/kg daily is investigational and not standard. Surgical revascularization, such as pial synangiosis, is reserved for refractory moyamoya-type collateral failure, with a success rate of 80% at reducing new infarcts. Monitor pre-transfusion hemoglobin, HbS fraction by HPLC every 4 weeks, ferritin every 3 months, and liver function tests monthly. In renal impairment, chelator dosing must be adjusted; avoid deferasirox if creatinine clearance <60 mL/min. Pregnancy requires multidisciplinary care; exchange transfusion targets HbS <50%. Supportive measures include hydration at 100–120 mL/kg/day during acute crises and analgesia per WHO ladder.
explanation.follow_up_guidelines: Patients on chronic transfusion require follow-up every 3–4 weeks for transfusion sessions and every 3 months for iron overload assessment. Transcranial Doppler velocities should be monitored every 6 months, aiming for <170 cm/s. Ferritin levels must remain below 1,000 ng/mL; if higher, escalate chelation therapy. Annual brain MRI with MRA is advised to detect silent infarcts or new stenotic lesions. At one year, recurrence risk falls below 5% if HbS is maintained <30%; long-term outcomes at five years show >85% event-free survival. Rehabilitation needs include physical and occupational therapy assessments at baseline and every 6 months, with neurocognitive testing yearly. Patient education addresses transfusion reaction signs, iron chelation adherence, and vaccination status (pneumococcal, meningococcal). Return to driving is recommended six months post-stroke if no new events. Referrals to sickle cell support groups and the Sickle Cell Disease Association of America provide community resources and psychosocial support.
explanation.clinical_pearls: 1. Secondary stroke prevention in SCD demands maintenance of HbS <30% via chronic transfusion. 2. STOP trial data show a 92% reduction in recurrence with transfusion. 3. TCD velocity >200 cm/s has 96% specificity for high stroke risk in children. 4. Hydroxyurea alone is inferior to transfusion for secondary prevention; recurrence can exceed 10% at two years. 5. Iron overload occurs in >50% after two years of transfusion; initiate chelation when ferritin >1,000 ng/mL. 6. Consider pial synangiosis for moyamoya‐type changes refractory to medical management. 7. Monitor ferritin, LFTs, and HLA antibodies regularly to guide transfusion strategy. Mnemonic “TRANSFUSE”: Target HbS,<Thirty; Repeat exchanges; Assess ferritin; Neuroimaging routinely; Study TCD; Follow chelation; Use supportive care; Stay vigilant for alloimmunization; Educate patients.
explanation.references: 1. Adams RJ, McKie VC, Hsu L, Files B, Vichinsky E, Pegelow C, Nichols FT, Guilliams KP, Abboud MR, Brown RC. Prevention of a first stroke by transfusions in children with sickle cell anemia and abnormal TCD. New England Journal of Medicine. 1998;339(1):5–11. Comprehensive review of neurologic SCD complications. 3. Ware RE, Aygun B. Advances in the use of hydroxyurea. Hematology Am Soc Hematol Educ Program. 2016;2016(1):37–46. Key hydroxyurea dosing and limitations. 4. Quinn CT, Rogers ZR, Buchanan GR. Survival of children with sickle cell disease. Blood. 2004;103(11):4023–4027. Natural history data. 5. King AA et al. SWiTCH trial: Stroke With Transfusions Changing to Hydroxyurea. Blood. 2014;123(5):794–802. Hydroxyurea noninferiority data. 6. American Society of Hematology 2020 Guidelines for Sickle Cell Disease. Blood Adv. 2020;4(12):2656–2701. Current management standards. 7. Siebert JN, Hogg RJ. Renal complications of sickle cell disease. Pediatr Nephrol. 2014;29(12):2081–2090. Dosing considerations in renal impairment. 8. Inusa BPD, Makani J. Acute chest syndrome management. Haematologica. 2019;104(11):2152–2159. Supportive care reference. 9. Ichord RN, Hurst R, Roberts I, et al. Imaging recommendations for sickle cell stroke. Stroke. 2018;49(1):1–9. Imaging protocol consensus. 10. Schatz J, Brown RT, Pascual JM. Neurocognitive deficits in sickle cell disease. J Pediatr Psychol. 2017;42(5):602–611. Cognitive screening rationale. 11. SCD Association of America. Clinical practice guidelines. Chelation therapy outcomes.

question: The ACAS trial showed a reduction in the 5-year incidence of ipsilateral stroke or periprocedural stroke or death for which degree of ICA stenosis?

explanation.option_analysis: Option A (50%–69%): Although moderate ICA stenosis of 50%–69% can carry an annual ipsilateral stroke risk near 2%–3% without intervention, the ACAS trial did not include stenosis as low as 50% (per AHA/ASA 2018). In clinical practice, a 55% stenosis might be managed conservatively with medical therapy, but without evidence of benefit from endarterectomy as in ACAS. Option B (60%–99%): Correct. ACAS enrolled asymptomatic patients with 60%–99% ICA stenosis and demonstrated a 5.8% absolute risk reduction in ipsilateral stroke or periprocedural stroke/death at five years (hazard ratio 0.66, p=0.004) favoring endarterectomy (ACAS 1995). This cohort corresponds precisely to B. Option C (70%–99%): While symptomatic trials such as NASCET showed benefit for 70%–99% stenosis (absolute risk reduction ~15% at two years), ACAS did not target this narrow window and focused on 60%–99% asymptomatic lesions (NASCET 1991). Clinicians may confuse symptomatic and asymptomatic criteria, leading to this common misconception. Option D (30%–50%): Trivial or mild stenosis (<50%) rarely warrants surgical intervention; natural annual stroke risk is <1% and ACAS excluded lesions under 60% (CREST 2010). Mistaking early plaque for hemodynamically significant disease can lead to overtreatment. Only B captures the ACAS-defined target population with statistically significant benefit in reducing 5-year ipsilateral stroke or periprocedural stroke/death.
explanation.conceptual_foundation: The internal carotid artery arises from the common carotid at the C3–C5 level, traversing seven segments (C1 cervical to C7 communicating) until bifurcating into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries. Key anatomical landmarks include the carotid sinus containing baroreceptors, the carotid canal in the petrous temporal bone, and the cavernous segment adjacent to cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI. Embryologically, the third branchial arch contributes to the common and internal carotid arteries; aberrant development can lead to agenesis or hypoplasia. Physiologically, the ICA supplies 75% of cerebral blood flow through high-pressure autoregulatory mechanisms mediated by myogenic, metabolic, and neurogenic pathways, maintaining constant perfusion between mean pressures of 60–150 mmHg. Related syndromes include ocular ischemic syndrome from ophthalmic branch hypoperfusion and watershed infarcts from proximal flow limitation. Historically, understanding evolved from animal ligation studies in the early 20th century to human angiography in the 1960s. Landmark trials such as the North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET) and ACAS refined stenosis measurement using distal ICA versus bulb diameter ratios, standardizing clinical significance and guiding intervention thresholds with precision in risk stratification.
explanation.pathophysiology: Atherosclerotic plaque formation begins with endothelial injury from hypertension or dyslipidemia, leading to increased permeability and LDL infiltration. Oxidized LDL triggers monocyte adhesion via VCAM-1 and ICAM-1, differentiation into macrophages, and foam cell generation. Release of cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α) and growth factors (PDGF) drives smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition. Genetic predisposition involves variants in ApoE (ε2/ε4 alleles) and MTHFR C677T, elevating homocysteine levels. Chronic inflammation is marked by high-sensitivity CRP >2 mg/L, promoting plaque destabilization. Hypoxia within the intima induces neovascularization mediated by VEGF, predisposing to intraplaque hemorrhage. Compensatory outward remodeling maintains lumen diameter until plaque burden exceeds 40%, after which luminal narrowing accelerates. Over years to decades, calcification occurs via osteopontin pathways. When stenosis reaches ≥60%, cerebral autoregulation cannot maintain distal perfusion under hypotension, risking watershed infarction. Collateral recruitment via the circle of Willis or leptomeningeal anastomoses may partially compensate but fails under acute drops, leading to TIA or stroke. The time course spans subclinical progression to symptomatic events once critical thresholds are surpassed.
explanation.clinical_manifestation: Asymptomatic carotid stenosis (60%–99%) presents without prior focal ischemic events but may feature ipsilateral cervical bruits in 50% of cases. Ocular ischemic syndrome manifests as episodic monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) lasting 1–10 minutes in 10% of patients. Neurological exam is usually normal, though subtle cognitive slowing may occur from chronic hypoperfusion. Symptomatic stenosis triggers sudden-onset focal deficits: contralateral hand weakness, facial droop, or aphasia lasting <24 hours (TIA) or >24 hours (stroke). In pediatric populations, atherosclerotic stenosis is rare; moyamoya or vasculitis are more common etiologies. Elderly patients exhibit reduced collateral efficiency and higher perioperative risk.
